benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Add custom fields to account

covered: POST Valid Payload: TC01, TC03, TC04, TC05 cover successful creation with valid headers and bodies and different account states

Invalid Payload/Bad Input: TC06 (invalid accountId), TC07 (missing required header), TC08 (malformed JSON), TC09 (empty body), TC11 (unsupported fields), TC12 (duplicate field names), TC18 (SQL injection), TC19 (XSS), TC26 (empty custom fields array), TC28 (invalid data types), TC30 (null values handling) cover various input validation paths
Security/Input Validation: TC18, TC19, TC28, TC30 address injection/XSS/invalid types and nulls
Boundary/Size: TC14 (maximum payload size), TC15 (payload exceeding size)
Existence/State: TC04 (account with no custom fields), TC05 (account with existing fields), TC10 (non-existent account)
Headers/Auth: TC01 (required header), TC02 (optional headers), TC03 (only required header), TC16 (unauthorized), TC17 (service unavailable) cover header/auth behavior and service availability
gaps: Authorization edge cases beyond basic header presence (e.g., 403 vs 401 nuances) not explicitly tested
Rate limiting / throttling scenarios are not covered
Pagination is not relevant for POST but no explicit mention of handling extremely large results (e.g., after creation) is needed
Server error variety beyond 503 (e.g., 500 Internal Server Error) not explicitly tested
Duplicate Submissions: no explicit test ensuring idempotency or handling of repeated identical requests
Caching behavior: not applicable for POST in most cases, but no explicit validation of caching headers is performed
recommendations: Add a test for 500 Internal Server Error scenario to complement 503 service unavailable (e.g., simulate DB failure) to align with server error handling guideline
Add rate limiting/throttling tests to validate behavior under rapid consecutive requests
Add an idempotency/duplicate submission test (same payload sent twice) to confirm graceful handling
Consider a dedicated authorization test with explicit 403 vs 401 outcomes if applicable in the system, to strengthen auth coverage
If applicable, include a test verifying no unintended data exposure when invalid payloads are rejected (security hardening)
